2025-10-29 · properly-fucked

In a move designed to illuminate the often-murky waters of corporate remuneration, Labour is tabling a new bill that would compel larger New Zealand employers to lay bare their pay structures. The Pay Transparency Bill, spearheaded by Labour women’s spokesperson Carmel Sepuloni, promises to shine a light on disparities in the hope of fostering fairer workplaces.

One can only imagine the collective gasp of surprise when, after years of diligent reporting, it is revealed that, yes, men continue to earn more than women for what is, by all reasonable metrics, the same job. This revelation, presumably, will be met with the same incredulous wonder as discovering that water is wet, or that politicians occasionally make promises. The sheer audacity of such an enduring disparity, now quantified and laid out in neat columns, promises a thrilling new chapter in the ongoing saga of 'things we already suspected but now have a spreadsheet for.',Employers, no doubt, are already bracing themselves for the arduous task of 'shining a light' on what many have historically preferred to keep in the shadows. This will, of course, involve extensive internal reviews, possibly a few carefully worded press releases about 'legacy issues,' and perhaps even the commissioning of a consultancy firm to explain precisely why the light, once shone, reveals exactly what everyone thought it would.

The process itself, a triumph of bureaucratic diligence, will undoubtedly be as transparent as the data it seeks to unveil.,The notion that merely knowing the extent of the problem will magically dissolve it is, in itself, a testament to a certain kind of optimism. It's akin to believing that if one simply publishes the precise dimensions of a leaky roof, the rain will somehow cease to fall indoors. While the water ingress is now meticulously documented, the actual act of climbing onto the roof with tools and sealant remains an entirely separate, and often less appealing, proposition. But at least we'll have a very accurate record of how much water is coming in, and who it's landing on.,And so, another legislative lever is pulled, another 'proven way' to tackle gaps is enacted.

One can almost hear the collective sigh of relief from those who believe that the path to equality is paved with ever-increasing layers of public disclosure, each one a tiny, incremental step towards a future where the numbers finally align. The sheer, relentless optimism that a new form will solve an old problem is, if nothing else, consistently admirable.

Source: https://www.stuff.co.nz/politics/360869192/labour-seeks-force-large-employers-report-gender-ethnic-pay-gaps

What’s fucked

The fundamental issue, of course, is that the pay gap exists at all, suggesting a deeply entrenched and often unacknowledged bias in how work is valued and compensated. It's pretty fucked that a legislative act is required to compel employers to simply be transparent about something as basic as what they pay their staff. The underlying societal assumptions that allow these disparities to persist are profoundly fucked, making any 'solution' feel like a band-aid on a gaping wound.

What might unfuck

The most optimistic outcome is that public reporting and mandatory pay ranges might genuinely pressure some employers to review and adjust their remuneration practices, particularly those with the most egregious disparities. Increased transparency could, in theory, empower employees to negotiate more effectively or expose companies with particularly bad records, leading to some marginal improvements.

Odds of unfucking

The odds of this bill alone completely unfucking the entrenched pay gap are slim to none. While it might nudge a few numbers in the right direction, the systemic issues contributing to these gaps are far more complex than simple lack of transparency. Expect incremental shifts, not a revolution. The deeply rooted biases that create these disparities are not easily dislodged by a spreadsheet.
